Inleidend
In sy testament het wyle J.J. Strauss ("Strauss") sy plaas, Simonsium, bemaak
aan sy seun, A.L. Strauss ( "die insolvent"). Twee ander
plase van Strauss is
bemaak aan sy twee dogters, H.J. Myburgh en M.M. Sinclair. Hierdie bemakings is
onderworpe gestel aan 'n vruggebruik
ten gunste van Strauss se eggenote asook
aan die volgende bepaling:
"Dit sal 'n kondisie wees dat sou enige van my drie kinders wat die
bogenoemde eiendomme erf te sterwe mag kom sonder wettige afstammelinge
sal sy
of haar deel gaan na sy of haar dood na die orige twee kinders in gelyke dele of
hulle wettige afstammelinge by plaasvervulling.
"
Sy eggenote en al drie sy kinders het Strauss oor-leef en na sy dood is
Simonsium na die insolvent oorgedra onderhewig aan die genoemde
vruggebruik en
voorwaarde. Gedurende 1975 het die Vrystaatse Provinsiale Afdeling egter op
aansoek van die insolvent 'n bevel verleen

plaas te vervreem en gelas is dat drie stukke grond, die eiendom van A.L.

Frederik Strauss ge-dateer 2 September 1955."

sections.facts: The deceased Jacob Frederik Strauss bequeathed his farm Simonsium to his son A.L. Strauss (the "insolvent") subject to a usufruct for Strauss's widow and a condition that, should any of his three children die without lawful descendants, the share would pass to the surviving children or their lawful descendants. Two other farms were bequeathed to his daughters. After Strauss’s death the farm passed to the insolvent under the same conditions. In 1975 the Free State Provincial Division, on application of the insolvent, issued a court order allowing the farm to be sold, and an endorsement was entered on the title of A.L. Strauss (Edms) Bpk, indicating that the land remained subject to the usufruct and the conditional clause. The insolvent later became bankrupt, and the appellant, acting as liquidator of the company and curator of the insolvent’s estate, sought a further order confirming that the fiduciary rights derived from Strauss’s will did not create a fideicommissary right for the children’s descendants.
sections.issues: The principal issue was whether the testamentary condition – a sine liberis clause coupled with a conditional substitution – gave rise to a tacit (fideicommissum tacitum) in favour of the liberi (descendants of the testator). Specifically, the court had to decide if paragraph 2(c) of the lower‑court order, which held that the estate did not contain a fideicommissary right for the descendants, should be upheld or set aside.
sections.principles: The court examined Roman‑Dutch common law on sine liberis clauses, noting that such a clause does not automatically create a fideicommissum tacitum unless the testator’s intention is clearly expressed, especially where the liberi are direct descendants. Authorities considered included Estate Cato v Estate Cato, Steenkamp v Marais, Galliers v Rycroft, and the writings of Van der Merwe, Rowland, and others. The prevailing principle is that a presumption in favour of a fideicommissary benefit arises only when the testator’s intent is evident; otherwise the condition is merely a restriction on ownership.
sections.application: Applying these principles, the court interpreted Strauss’s will as containing sufficient indication that he intended the children’s descendants to benefit from the property should a child die without issue. The endorsement on the title confirmed that the fiduciary rights were limited by the testamentary condition. Consequently, the lower court’s conclusion that no fideicommissary right existed was contrary to the applicable legal rule, leading the appellate court to set aside paragraph 2(c) (specifically sub‑para 1.2) of the order.
sections.conclusion: The Supreme Court of Appeal overturned the lower court’s finding on paragraph 2(c) and affirmed that the fiduciary rights over the three parcels of land were subject to the testamentary condition, thereby recognising a tacit fideicommissary benefit for the liberi. The appeal was allowed on this point, costs were awarded, and the costs order was made jointly recoverable from the insolvent’s estate and the liquidated company.
